net.cloud.gfx.elements

Interface Element

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Focusable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    DecoratorElement
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractButton, AbstractDecoratorElement, AbstractElement, AbstractModalDialog, Button, CenteredText, Checkbox, ConfirmationDialog, DraggableElement, FramedElement, HorizontalView, HorizontalView.HorizontalViewElement, ImageButton, InputDialog, Interface, LoginInterface, MessageDialog, PasswordField, PriorityContainer, QuasiRoot, RadioButton, ReferenceText, ScrollView, ScrollView.Scrollbar, SelectableButton, Sprite, SpriteTestInterface, TestElement, TestModalDialog, Text, TextArea, TextField, TiledSprite, VerticalView, VerticalView.VerticalViewElement

    public interface Element
extends Focusable
    A graphic element. This is the root of the graphic element hierarchy. It's fair to compare it to Swing components, but [hopefully] lightweight and more custom-purposed.
    Each element will be responsible for drawing itself, and handling mouse and key events that occur on it. Drawing and mouse events are handled top-down from the root element, while key events mitigate bottom-up from the element that currently has focus. To clarify, the propagation of these events is primarily along the container hierarchy rather than by class.

    Element defines a coordinate (X,Y) and dimensions (width, height) although subclasses may call the width and height 0 if there is no need.
    This class also keeps track of whether or not it has focus. This class will mitigate key events to the parent element, if there is a parent element. Otherwise, no action will be done.
    When the element is clicked, the only action taken is to register the new focus through the controlling class.

    • Method Detail

      • drawElement

        void drawElement(java.awt.Graphics g,
                 int offsetX,
                 int offsetY)
          throws IteratorException
        Draw this element to the provided graphics object. The drawing is done using the provided offsets, to account for the container hierarchy. Drawing coordinates should add the offset coordinates with the element's coordinates to obtain the location for this element to draw at.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - How far off on the X axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        offsetY - How far off on the Y axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • clicked

        void clicked(Element clicked,
             java.awt.Point relPoint,
             boolean isRightClick)
        Register that this element has focus, both with the local variable and the controlling class. Aside from that, no special action is taken. If a subclass does override this method, it should certainly call super.elementClicked(...) or perform the focus 'attenuation' itself.
        Parameters:
        clicked - The element that was clicked. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of click, relative to this element
        isRightClick - True if the right mouse button was clicked

      • pressed

        void pressed(Element pressed,
             java.awt.Point relPoint)
        The element had a mouse press happen on it. This will set a flag, so subclasses may override this method but should call either super.pressed(...) or super.setPressed(true)
        Parameters:
        pressed - The element that was pressed. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of click, relative to this element

      • released

        void released(Element released,
              java.awt.Point relPoint,
              boolean onElement)
        This is called when either of two things happens: The mouse button is released over the element, or the element was the element that was currently pressed down and is being notified that it should no longer be down. In the case that both are true, the method is only called once - for the release on top of the element.
        May be overridden, but should call super.released or super.setPressed(false)
        Parameters:
        released - The element that was released. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of release, relative to this element. Invalid and null if the release is not on the element.
        onElement - True when the mouse release is over this element

      • dragged

        void dragged(Element dragged,
             java.awt.Point start,
             java.awt.Point withinStart,
             java.awt.Point current)
        Called when this element is being dragged. (The mouse is pressed down on the element and moving) The provided points are relative to the space the element is in, unlike the other mouse event methods, which are relative to within the element.
        The default behavior is that an Element discards the event.
        Parameters:
        dragged - The element that was dragged. It may not be this element!
        start - Where the dragging started. I.e. where the mouse was first pressed down
        withinStart - The point within the element dragging started. Like with the other mouse events.
        current - Where the mouse is currently at. Can be used to find a movement delta or used directly.

      • keyTyped

        void keyTyped(char key)
        Does two things. First, will check to see if the event is telling us that we should change focus over to the next thing in line. This behavior can be stopped by intercepting the CHANGE_FOCUS_NEXT event.
        Otherwise, the event will be passed to the parent Element, if there is a parent. If a subclass overrides this for interest in some keys but not all, it should certainly call super.keyTyped(key) to allow the other keys to propagate. (Chain of responsibility)
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Focusable
        Parameters:
        key - The character which was typed

      • focusGained

        void focusGained()
        Informs this element and its focus handler that focus was gained. Elements overriding this for custom behavior should call super.focusGained()
        Specified by:
        focusGained in interface Focusable

      • focusLost

        void focusLost()
        Informs this element and its focus handler that focus was lost Elements overriding this for custom behavior should call super.focusGained()
        Specified by:
        focusLost in interface Focusable

      • topElementAtPoint

        Element topElementAtPoint(java.awt.Point point)
                   throws IteratorException
        Finds the element which is showing on the point. Mostly useful for containers, which will traverse down the child hierarchy. However, elements in general may still be composed of multiple elements and may want to preserve their behavior independently.
        The point is translated to the relative space for the found element, so it may be passed to event methods that require a relative point
        Parameters:
        point - The point relative to this element
        Returns:
        The element showing on top. By default, returns this instance
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

        Returns:
        The bounding rectangle, contains all of the coordinate information

      • getPriority

        int getPriority()
        Returns:
        Essentially the Z coordinate. Higher is on top.

      • setPriority

        void setPriority(int priority)
        Parameters:
        priority - The new priority of the element. This will not have an effect unless re-added to the container.

      • getFocusHandler

        FocusHandler getFocusHandler()
        Description copied from interface: Focusable
        Obtain the FocusHandler underlying this Focusable object. The handler will take care of tracking focus and and chain of focusable objects for changing focus. This should never be null. That would not be cool.
        Specified by:
        getFocusHandler in interface Focusable
        Returns:
        The handler taking care of focus actions for this element

      • setFocusHandler

        void setFocusHandler(FocusHandler focusHandler)
        Parameters:
        focusHandler - The handler that will take care of focus actions for this elements

        Returns:
        An Optional which may contain the element containing this one

        Parameters:

        Parameters:
